misconceptions.name: Implemented a completely different program than the specification
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a distance-between-points calculator instead of a grade calculator, indicating a misunderstanding or disregard of the problem specification.
misconceptions.student_belief: For this question, I should write a program that reads two points and prints the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, you should read a single numeric grade (0–100) and print the corresponding letter grade (A–F) using conditional statements based on the specified ranges.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade value.
No conditional (if/else) logic is present to map numeric ranges to letter grades.
Output describes the distance between two points, not a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different assignment questions, copy-pasting code from another exercise, or not carefully reading the problem statement for this specific question.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and restate it in your own words before coding. Start by writing code that reads ONE numeric grade, then design an if–else chain that checks which range (90–100, 80–89, etc.) the grade falls into and prints the correct letter.
related_concepts: Basic program design (mapping inputs to required outputs)
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (input prompts, variables, calculations, and output) is focused on distance between points and does not reference grades or letter outputs at all.

evidence.note: The code clearly solves a distance-between-points problem rather than reading a grade and mapping it to a letter.

misconceptions.name: Submitted Code for Wrong Problem
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a program calculating the distance between two points instead of the required Grade Calculator program (Q3).
misconceptions.student_belief: The file 'DistanceBetweenPoints.java' containing the distance calculation logic is the correct solution for Q3: Grade Calculator.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The solution for Q3: Grade Calculator must implement conditional logic specific to grade ranges (90+, 80-89, etc.) and read only one input (the numeric grade).
symptoms: Program reads four coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one numeric grade.
Program calculates the distance formula instead of using conditional logic for grading.
The output message is related to points and distance, not letter grades.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely uploaded the wrong file or misinterpreted which problem they were supposed to solve/submit for Q3.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment prompt for Q3 and ensure you submit the file that implements the Grade Calculator logic.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student code explicitly calculates distance between two points (as indicated by variable names and the use of Math.sqrt) and does not contain any functional elements of a grade calculator.

evidence.note: The entire logic block calculates distance, demonstrating that the code submitted is for Q1 (Distance Between Points) rather than Q3 (Grade Calculator).

misconceptions.name: Task misalignment - solving wrong problem
misconceptions.description: The student appears to have solved a completely different problem (distance between two points) instead of the assigned grade calculator problem. This suggests either a fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment requirements or copying code from a different exercise.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes they should write a program to calculate the Euclidean distance between two coordinate points.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assigned task is to read a numeric grade (0-100) and output the corresponding letter grade (A/B/C/D/F) based on specified ranges. The distance calculation program is unrelated to the grade calculator problem.
symptoms: Program reads x1, y1, x2, y2 coordinates instead of a numeric grade
Program calculates distance using Math.sqrt instead of comparing grade ranges
Output shows distance calculation instead of letter grade mapping
No conditional logic for grade boundaries (90-100, 80-89, 70-79, 60-69, <60)
Class is named DistanceBetweenPoints, not related to grades
misconceptions.root_cause: The student may have submitted code from a previous exercise without reading the current assignment, or fundamentally misunderstood what problem Q3 asks them to solve.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. You need to: (1) read ONE numeric grade value, (2) use if-else statements to check which range (90-100, 80-89, etc.) it falls into, (3) print the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: This is absolutely certain - the submitted code solves an entirely different problem. The assignment explicitly states 'Write a program that reads a numeric grade (0-100)' and provides a sample run showing grade input and letter output.

evidence.note: Student reads coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single numeric grade value.

System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distanceBetweenPoints);
evidence.note: Program calculates Euclidean distance instead of mapping a grade to a letter grade.
Class name indicates a distance calculation program, unrelated to grade calculator.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Program solves a different problem than the specification
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a distance-between-points calculator instead of a grade-to-letter converter, suggesting a misunderstanding of the assignment requirements or a tendency to ignore the written specification.
misconceptions.student_belief: As long as my program compiles, reads some numbers, and performs a meaningful calculation, it adequately answers the question, even if it doesn't follow the exact problem description.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must directly implement the specified behavior: read a single numeric grade (0–100), use conditional statements to classify it into A/B/C/D/F based on the given ranges, and print the corresponding letter grade. Any solution that computes something else, even if correct for another problem, does not satisfy this question.
symptoms: Prompts for coordinates ('Enter x1 and y1', 'Enter x2 and y2') instead of a grade.
Computes a Euclidean distance using Math.sqrt and squared differences.
Outputs 'The distance of the two points is ...' instead of 'Letter grade: ...'.
No conditional statements (if/else) are present to handle grade ranges.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between exercises or reusing code from a previous problem without carefully reading this question's requirements. The student may focus on writing code that compiles rather than mapping the problem statement to the necessary input, processing, and output.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the assignment carefully and rewrite the program specifically for the grade-conversion task: prompt for a single numeric grade, store it in a variable, then use if/else-if/else statements to check the ranges (90–100, 80–89, etc.) and print the correct letter grade. Before coding, outline the required inputs, decisions, and outputs to ensure they match the problem.
related_concepts: Mapping numeric ranges to categorical outputs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is a standard distance-formula solution and does not overlap at all with the described grade-calculation behavior, indicating the student is implementing a different task.

evidence.note: All input, processing, and output logic is for computing distance between two points; there is no grade input, no conditional logic, and no letter grade output.

misconceptions.name: Task Mismatch / Code Submission Error

misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the submitted code fulfills the requirements for the Grade Calculator problem, or they submitted output from a previous, unrelated assignment instead of the current one.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The submitted code must address the specified requirements of the problem (Q3: Grade Calculator). The submitted code addresses a different problem (Distance Between Points).
symptoms: Code implements coordinate input and distance formula, not grade calculation logic.
File/class name is 'DistanceBetweenPoints' instead of something related to 'Grade'.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of which file to submit, confusion between assignments, or failure to delete boilerplate code and start the correct solution.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment carefully and submit the correct code written to solve the Grade Calculator problem description. Ensure the main method logic implements conditional statements based on the input grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The supplied code solves the distance formula problem (Q1 or Q2 typically), which is entirely unrelated to the requested Q3 Grade Calculator problem, resulting in zero points.

misconceptions.name: Problem Misidentification - Solved Wrong Problem
misconceptions.description: The student has written code to solve a completely different problem (calculating distance between two points) rather than implementing a grade calculator. This demonstrates a fundamental failure to understand or parse the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe (or has acted as though) the assignment requires reading two coordinate pairs and calculating the Euclidean distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and using conditional logic to determine and output the corresponding letter grade (A/B/C/D/F) based on specified ranges.
symptoms: Program reads x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade value
Program calculates and outputs distance between points, not letter grades
No conditional logic (if/else) for grade range checking
Variable names and computation are for coordinate geometry, not grading
misconceptions.root_cause: Possible causes: (1) Student read the wrong problem specification, (2) Student copied code from a previous assignment without careful review, (3) Student submitted the wrong file, or (4) Fundamental misunderstanding of assignment requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Start over: Read the grade from keyboard input. Store it in a single variable. Use if/else statements to check which range the grade falls into (≥90, ≥80, ≥70, ≥60, or <60). Output the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: 100% confidence. The code solves an entirely different problem (distance between points) with completely different I/O than the assignment specification (grade calculator). This is not a minor logic error—it's a fundamental mismatch between assignment and submission.
